cluster_relations.rel_desc: The beastly exterior is the outward appearance of the cursed prince (the Beast).
cluster_relations.object_entity_name: Beast (cursed prince in "Beauty and the Beast")
cluster_relations.object_class_label: Beauty and the Beast Characters and Motifs

qualifiers.TemporalQualifier: while he is under the curse

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The Beast (cursed prince) possesses a true inner nature distinct from his outward beastly form.
cluster_relations.subject_entity_name: Beast (cursed prince in "Beauty and the Beast")
cluster_relations.subject_class_label: Beauty and the Beast Characters and Motifs
cluster_relations.object_class_label: Beauty and the Beast Characters and Motifs

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The power of storytelling is a property or capacity of the practice of storytelling.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: PowerType: capacity to connect and convey meaning

remarks: Relation used to link the abstract 'power' concept back to the base practice node.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Links an outward or physical appearance to the character or entity whose appearance it is.
args.justification: The subject is a specific outward form ('beastly exterior') and the object is the entity it visually represents (the cursed prince); this is best modeled as an appearance-to-bearer predicate.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Links a character or entity to their true or inner nature, distinct from outward appearance.
args.justification: The Beast entity is linked to his 'true nature of the prince', which is an internal, enduring quality; a has_inner_nature predicate captures this direction and semantics.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Relates a property or capacity to the practice or bearer in which it inheres.
args.justification: The 'power of storytelling' is an abstract capacity that belongs to the practice 'storytelling'; in ontology practice this is typically modeled as a property that inheres in its bearer.

Both relations link a character (the Beast) to character-centric attributes (outward appearance and inner nature); grouping them under a shared character_attribute_relation class reflects this narrative-attribute focus.

This relation connects an abstract property ('power of storytelling') to its bearer practice ('storytelling'); this fits a more general property_bearer_relation class rather than a narrow character-focused attribute class.

All three predicates express attribute-like or property-bearing relations: appearance of a character, inner nature of a character, and a power that inheres in a practice; these are best grouped under a broad ATTRIBUTE dimension.
